awd_titl_txt: Development and Field Testing of a Spectral Radiometer for Measurements in Extremely Low-Light Marine Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Low-light conditions in the ocean have critical significance in the lives of marine animals due to various light-dependent physiological mechanisms and behavioral patterns associated with animal vision, communication, reproduction, predation, antipredator tactics, and vertical migration within the water column. Therefore, low-light environments have multiple implications for oceanic habitats, water quality, and commercial fisheries production. Measurements of extremely low-light marine environments including twilight (sunset and sunrise) conditions in the surface ocean layer as well as very dim solar daylight within deeper layers extending from about 200 to 1000 m depth are not possible with existing conventional instruments. As a result, such measurements have been very scarce and greatly limited in scope. The instrument to be developed in this project, called LARS (Low-light Aquatic Radiometer System), will have an unparalleled capability to accurately measure extremely low light, which will pave the way to improved characterization of deep-sea light and twilight conditions in the ocean beyond oversimplifying historical descriptions. This instrument will aid in expanding research of deep-sea habitats to protect the biodiversity and integrity of these largest ecosystems by volume on Earth, an important goal recognized by international community of scientists and policy-makers.

The proposed development of LARS will be based on state-of-the-art highly sensitive photon counting technology which will allow measurements of extremely low levels of underwater spectral irradiance of 10 - 20 photons/(cm2 s nm) within the visible spectral range. This will enable measurements of dim daylight at ocean mesopelagic depths (~200-1000 m) not only of blue light but also, for the first time, potentially biologically significant levels of green and red light generated locally at depth by inelastic radiative processes such as Raman scattering by water molecules. In addition, LARS will provide the capability to measure both the downward and upward irradiances in low-light marine environments, which has never been done before. Field demonstrative data will be collected to comprehensively characterize the deep-sea light field and provide first experimental evidence for the role of inelastic processes and approach to the asymptotic light regime at depth. The measurements of poorly characterized twilight and moonlight conditions in the ocean surface layer will be also demonstrated. The broader utility of LARS will be demonstrated by data analysis in support of the study of specific biological questions related to low-light marine habitats.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Low-light environments in the ocean are of critical significance to marine life, especially many species of marine animals which have various light-dependent physiological mechanisms and behavioral patterns associated with vision, communication, reproduction, predation, and antipredator tactics. The low-light environments of significance to marine animals occur within the so-called mesopelagic zone of the ocean defined as the water column between a depth of 200 m and 1000 m. Low-light environments are also common in the surface ocean layer during periods of twilight near sunset and sunrise, at night when moonlight can serve as a source of low-light conditions, as well as during polar night at high latitudes. However, measurements to comprehensively characterize the intensity and spectral composition (i.e., proportions of blue, green, and red light) of ambient natural light in these low-light environments are not possible with currently available instruments. The scarcity and fragmentary nature of light measurements in low-light marine environments is astounding. This has resulted, for example, in misconceptions or oversimplifying descriptions of the mesopelagic light field which most likely underestimate the potential role of green and red light in deep-sea habitats because the role of local generation of green and red light at depths from blue light through the so-called inelastic radiative processes has been ignored. A need for addressing a major technological gap for high sensitivity light measurements at different light wavelengths from the blue through green into the red in low-light marine environments provided the motivation for this project. The main goal of this project was to develop and test a novel instrument referred to as the Low-light Aquatic Radiometer System (LARS) for measurements of ambient natural light within the visible spectral range in the ocean under conditions of low-light environments such as mesopelagic depths, twilight, moonlight, and polar night conditions.

We developed a prototype of LARS using state-of-the-art highly sensitive photon counting technology which will provide an unprecedented capability for measuring extremely low levels of underwater irradiance within the visible spectral range. This will enable measurements at mesopelagic depths not only of blue light but also, for the first time, potentially biologically significant levels of green and red light generated locally at depth by inelastic radiative processes. An additional unique capability of LARS is the measurement of both the downward and upward irradiances in low-light marine environments which, to our knowledge, has never been done before. The LARS prototype has been designed, assembled, and tested in the laboratory but has not yet reached the level of readiness for deployments at sea although we expect that the first field tests will provide demonstrative data and experimental evidence in support of unique capabilities of this novel technology. The broader utility of LARS is expected to be demonstrated in the near future when the instrument is used in various research projects, especially in relation to the study of various biological questions associated with low-light marine habitats. For example, it is anticipated that measurements with LARS will fill a gap in observational needs for future deep-sea observing systems and programs. This will contribute to expanding research of deep-sea habitats and protecting the biodiversity and integrity of these ecosystems, which has been broadly recognized as an important scientific goal.
